titleStmt.title: Mercurius publicus: comprising the sum of forraign intelligence ...[no.32 (2 Aug-9 Aug 1660)]
Mercurius publicus (London, England : 1659)
titleStmt.author: Muddiman, Henry, fl.1659-1666, editor.
Dury, Giles editor.
Newcomb, Thomas, d. 1681 or 2, publisher.

biblFull.extent: v. Began with numb. 1 (29 Dec. 1659-5 Jan. 1660); ceased with numb. 33 (13-20 Aug. 1663).

notesStmt.note: Subtitle varies: 1660, "... comprising the sum of forraign intelligence"; 1661-1663, "... comprising the sum of all affairs now in agitation."
By Henry Muddiman and Giles Dury. Cf. Nelson and Seccombe.
Printed variously by: John Macock, Thomas Newcomb, Richard Hodgkinson, D. Maxwell, Peter Lillicrap, James Cottrell.
Numb. 43 (18-25 Oct. 1660) is a second copy of The Parliamentary intelligencer for those dates, mistakenly titled Mercurius publicus.
Thomason collection does not have complete run.
Reels listed in chronological order of serial publication; holdings dispersed throughout collection.
Reproduction of the originals in the British Library.
Enumeration begins again at numb. 1 annually.
No issue numbered 52 in 1660, no issue numbered 44 in 1661; chronology is continuous.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.head: Numb. 32. Mercurius Publicus, COMPRISING The Sum of Forraign Intelligence: WITH The Affairs now in Agitation in England, Scotland, and Ireland. For Information of the People. Publi≈øhed by Order. From Thur≈øday Augu≈øt 2. to Thur≈øday Augu≈øt 9. 1660.
Am≈øterdam, Augu≈øt 2. S. N.
div.p: WE have expre≈øs news here from Genes, that four Hollands ≈øhips having rencountred five Turki≈øh Pyrates and engaged them, the Holland Ve≈ø≈øels had gotten the Victory, and taken three of them, on board of which there were ‚Ä¢ ound nine hundred Turks, whom they took pri≈øoners, the other two Ve≈ø≈øels were ≈øunk. We hear that the Bi≈øhop of Mun≈øter is gone with an Army of 5000. men to lye down before that City; but in regard this place is very ≈øtrong, and provided with all nece≈ø≈øaries, it is thought the Bi≈øhop will only keep it block'd up with eight Forts, which he cau≈øeth to be rai≈øed, on each of which he hath planted ten pieces of Cannon.

div.head: Toulou≈øe, July 4.
div.p: Here is no talk almo≈øt but of the great Earthquake which hapned the 11. of the la≈øt pa≈øt, of which it ≈øeemeth this place, Bordeux, Montau ‚Ä¢ an, Ca ‚Ä¢ ors, Limages, Angouleme, and other places farther off, have felt but the back-blow: At Bayonne it pa≈ø≈øed over but ≈øl ‚Ä¢ ghtly, but at Pau it flung down mo≈øt part of the chimnies, and at Bagnieres in Bigorre ≈øcituated on the top of the Pyrenean Mount, many hou≈øes are overthrown, and all tho≈øe that were within cru≈øh'd in pieces: A Mount of an extraordinary great height being opened above, rent a≈øunder, and became a pit of infinite depth. The Vallies of Crampan about the ≈øaid Town of Bagnieres, which of all the Country were mo≈øt inhabited, have ≈øuffered great hurt, e≈øpecially the Convent of the Capuchins of No≈øtre Dame of Medoux, where ≈øome of the Fathers dyed, and others that e≈øcaped, are ≈øorted to hide them≈øelves in ≈øome place or other thereabouts. That which is mo≈øt remarkable in this accident, is, that tho≈øe warm Baths which are at Bagnieres, were by a ≈øtrong vent of a ≈øubterranean fire in ≈øuch a mea≈øure enflamed, that tho≈øe who lived thereabouts, were con≈øtrined to retire thence. They write from Rou≈øillon, that Belver and Sea ‚Ä¢ d'Urgel, are re≈øtored to the Spaniard the 22. la≈øt pa≈øt, and Ro≈øes and Cap de Cuiers the 26.

div.head: Whitehal.
div.p: His Maje≈øty having Iune 22. received a congratulatory Letter from the Prince Elector Palatine, which was brought by that worthy Gentleman Chri≈øtopher Cl ‚Ä¢ s of Keyembergh, Captain of his Highne≈øs Life guard of Hor≈øe; he had audience, and was kindely received by His Maje≈øty, who told him he would take care to render an an≈øwer to the Prince Elector Palatine, which was done with ≈øuch di≈øpatch, that August 2. he ≈øet forward on his journey.

Tho. Sumptner Alderman, and Mr Nicholas Sudell of the Common Council of Pre≈øton in Lanca≈øhire, being favoured with the company of Sir George Booth, Sir Robert Binglo≈ø≈øe,
Sir Ralph A≈øhton, Sir Gilbert Ireland, and Colonel We≈øt, pre≈øented his Maje≈øty a ≈øurrender of a Fee-farm Rent purcha≈øed by that Town for the pre≈øervation of their Liberties in the late time of di≈øtraction. Take their own words.

body.head: To the Kings mo≈øt Excellent Maje≈øty.
body.p:
WE your Maje≈øties mo≈øt obedient ≈øubjects, The Mayor, Bayliffs, and Burge≈ø≈øes of your Burrough and Town of Pre≈øton in Amounderne≈øse in the County Palatine of Lanca≈øter, do mo≈øt humbly make this publique Repre≈øentation of our joyful and thankful acknowledgement of that univer≈øal happine≈øs and ≈øatisfaction which God hath brought us, in the repo≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the Throne by your mo≈øt „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ Maje≈øty; of which happy revolution, as we canno ‚Ä¢
„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ pre≈øent admini≈øtration of the mo≈øt eminent „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ of the indubitable and inviolably Sacred Title of your Maje≈øty, and the comfortable hopes that are bound up therein, o ‚Ä¢ future ≈øecurity and ≈øatisfaction to all good men, through that famous prudence, piety, and ≈øweetne≈øs of your mo≈øt excellent d ‚Ä¢ ≈øpo≈øition, and Royal ≈øpirit, ≈øo we do in all humility a≈ø≈øure your Maje≈øty, of our unfained fidelity and affection to your Sacred Per≈øon, Crown, and Government, from our fealty and allegiance, from which no powers or pretence ≈øhall withdraw us; and for the ≈øupport whereof in its full ≈øecurity, ≈øplendour, and e≈øtabli≈øhment, we ≈øhall freely ≈øacrifice the deare≈øt things, of liberty, life, and fortune.

We mu≈øt confe≈øs, in tho≈øe inva≈øions made upon authority in the≈øe unhappy times, which have had ≈øo deep a reflection upon all the comforts of your Sacred Maje≈øty, we finde our ≈øelves involved, in the procurement thereof, by the contribution of our particular ≈øins and failings; and therefore do humbly pro≈øtrate our ≈øelves before your Royal Grace, as being well a≈ø≈øured, that your people ≈øhall not more de≈øirou≈øly implore, then your Maje≈øty impart your
Princely pardon, and knows how to con≈øider the nece≈ø≈øities and temptations of the times that we have lived under. We do therefore humbly pray your mo≈øt Excellent Maje≈øty to receive this Burrough Town and Incorporate Body, into your Royal Favour and Protection, and to be a ≈øupport and pre≈øervation to ≈øuch ju≈øt Liberties and Priviledges as have been granted to them by your Royal Predece≈ø≈øors of ble≈ø≈øed memory, and not to ≈øuffer any con≈øideration of ≈øuch fatal accidents of War as have fallen out in this place, or any mi≈ø-report thereof, to deprive us of that per≈øwa≈øion of our loyalty in your Maje≈øties thoughts, which we ≈øhall endeavour to pre≈øerve for ever, by the utmo≈øt contribution of our all to the ≈øervice and devotion of your Crown and Government. And whereas through the exigency of the late times, your fore≈øaid ≈øubjects were enforced for the pre≈øervation of this place from being invaded upon in tho≈øe rights granted to us by your Royal Predece≈ø≈øors, to purcha≈øe of tho≈øe that pretended to have authority to di≈øpo≈øe thereof, the Fee-farm Rent of fifteen pounds per annum due from this Town to your Maje≈øty; We do now in all humility, freely and cheerfully ≈øurrender and re≈øigne the ≈øame into your Maje≈øties hands, with all Title or Right which may any way be claimed or pretended to the ≈øame, humbly be≈øeeching your mo≈øt Excellent Maje≈øty to accept thereof, as al≈øo of the whole contents of this our mo≈øt ≈øubmi≈ø≈øive Congratulation and Addre≈øs, which as the unanimous chearful act of each of us, we have cau≈øed to be Sealed with the Common Seal of this Burrough, and Signed by our Mayor, for and in the name of the whole Commonalty, the 13 of Iuly, in the twelfth year of your Maje≈øties Reign over England, Scotland, Fran ‚Ä¢ e and Ireland.

div.p: His Maje≈øty was plea≈øed to accept it with expre≈ø≈øions of his affe ‚Ä¢ t ‚Ä¢ ons to that Town, and tho≈øe Gentlemen that came with them.

Thomas Clifford and Thomas Chaff E≈øqs; Members of Parliament, accompanied by Mr Chri≈øtofer Maynard, and Mr Gilbert Eveleigh Aldermen of the Borough of Totnes in the County of Devon, pre≈øented an Addre≈øs to his Maje≈øty, with an hundred pieces of Gold in a Gold-wrought Pur≈øe. The Addre≈øs followes:
To the KING's mo≈øt Excellent Maje≈øty. The humble Addre≈øs of the Town and Borough of Totnes in the County of Devon.
Mo≈øt gratious Soveraign,
THe rejoicings of our hearts, for the eminent appearing of the hand of God for your Maje≈øty in ≈øuch late miraculous revolutions, by overturning and overturning and overturning, even untill he had as it were with his own finger chalk'd out a path for your Maje≈øties happy Re≈øtauration to your Fathers Throne, cannot be confin'd within our own brea≈øts. We therefore humbly crave leave to expre≈øs our Congratulations, to offer the inwardne≈øs of our hearts for your Maje≈øties concerns‚ñ™ and to profe≈øs our ready obedience to your Royal Scepter.
Though we are of the lea≈øt among the Tribes, yet will we boa≈øt (as we may our antiquity) our entire Loyalty with the chiefe≈øt; of which there was lately a clear te≈øtimony, when this County, within which we are, appeared for and demanded a Free Parliament (which was al≈øo a leading ca≈øe to the re≈øt of the Kingdom, and was then the likelye≈øt way for your Maje≈øty to acquire your Rights, and we our own Priviledges) we then were ≈øo far engaged as to re≈øi≈øt even unto blood, two of our Inhabitants loo≈øing their lives in the di≈øpute.
And as an Evidence of our ≈øtill con≈øtant and affectionate Fidelity, we likewi≈øe tender by the hands of our Repre≈øentatives a free and willing Offering, though but a ≈ømall one, ≈øuch another as we pre≈øented to your Maje≈øty when you departed from us in the year 1646. when we could no longer
protect you, but your prevailing enemies „Äà‚óä„Äâ you as a Partridge on the mountains. The general decay of Trade ≈øince your Maje≈øties mo≈øt unfortunate ab≈øci≈øion from us has di≈øabled us from greater performances at pre≈øent; but we are now in hope of enlivening and quickning beams from your Maje≈øties gratious return, that may have al≈øo influence even on forrain Commerce and Trafique, and cau≈øe it again to flouri≈øh, by which we may be impowered more amply to expre≈øs our affections: A peace with Spain we ≈øuppo≈øe will much conduce to the effecting of this.
Pardon we humbly be≈øeech your Maje≈øty our pre≈øumption in mentioning the≈øe particulars; we ≈øhall forbear all other, and acquie≈øce with confidence in your Maje≈øties pious proceedings and determinations in the ≈øettlement both of Church and State, and that they may tend to the honour of God, your pro≈øperous Reign here, and everla≈øting glory hereafter, ≈øhall ever be the prayer of
(Sacred SIR) Your mo≈øt loyal and obedient Subjects.

This being after a ≈øhort Speech made by Mr Clifford
‚Ä¢ ead to his Maje≈øty, he received it graciou≈øly, giving them a≈ø≈øurance of his e≈øpecial care to encourage forrain Commerce, and vouch≈øafed them the honour of his hand.

div.head: ADVERTISEMENT. To all Mini≈øters, Church-Wardens, Con≈øtables, Head-b ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ o ‚Ä¢ g ‚Ä¢ s, and all other Officers whom it may concern‚ñ™
div.p:
WHereas there hapned a great lo≈øs by fire at the Town of
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ken ‚Ä¢ am in the County of Norffolk upon the Eleventh day of April 1659. to the value of 508 ‚Ä¢ . l. And upon Petition of the poor Inhabitants to His Maje≈øty, it hath plea≈øed the King with the advice of His Coun≈øel to grant His Gratious Letters Patents under the Great S ‚Ä¢ al for a Collection to be made in certain Counties of England, bearing ‚Ä¢ ate at We≈øtmin≈øter the Ninth day now of July la≈øt pa≈øt.

Since which time, ≈øome idle Vagabonds, and Rogues have ≈øtole or gained a Copy, and have induced ≈øome Printer to print the ≈øame, and are gone into ≈øome parts of the Counties with tho≈øe Papers, and ha ‚Ä¢ e cau≈øed, ≈øumms to be collected, as at Putney and „Äà‚óä„Äâ nea ‚Ä¢
London. Therefore it is de≈øired; That if any per≈øon what≈øoever ≈øhall come to any place with any ≈øuch B ‚Ä¢ ief not having the broad, Seal, that he or they may be apprehended and carried before a Ju≈øtice of the Peace, to an≈øwer to his „Äà‚óä„Äâ their Offence, no Bayle to be taken for them: He that takes them or any of them ≈øhall
have Twenty ≈øhillings for his pains, be≈øides what charges he is out, to be paid at the Hou≈øe of Mr Hugh Low at the White-Hare in Botolph lane near Billing≈øgate in London. Augu≈øt 6, 1660.
The Reader may be plea≈øed to take notice, that in the preceding News book of Aug. 6. there was a mi≈øtake in line ‚Ä¢ . of this Adverti≈øement, viz. July 4. for July 9.
Since our la≈øt, you have this alteration in the Army.

George Duke of Buckingham, is Col. of the Regiment that was Col. Gibbons. Arthur A ‚Ä¢ ≈øcot Capt. Lieut. Hen. Wa≈øhington Lieut. Col. Hen. Norwood Maj. John Gibbons Capt. Edw. Barh ‚Ä¢ m Capt. Tho. Paulden Capt. _____
Hampden Capt.
With the≈øe we will joyn th ‚Ä¢ ee other Companies of the ≈øame Regiment, which being con≈øtant to his Excellency, and appe ‚Ä¢ ring with him in Scotland, have not had the lea≈øt change, viz.
John Waller Capt. B ‚Ä¢ rth. Hender≈øon Lieut. William Knight En≈øigne.

William Richard≈øon Capt. Io≈øeph Cl ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
Lieut. William Pear≈øon En≈øigne.
Io≈ø. Hor≈øley Capt. Phineas Grooke Lieut. Well En≈øigne.

The Letters from Scotland tell us nothing of Import, ≈øave only that Capt.
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ffi ‚Ä¢
late Collector of the Shire of Aire, is committed Pri≈øoner to Edinburgh Ca≈øtle.

Though there hath been great indu≈øtry u≈øed for the apprehending of ≈øeveral per≈øons by the Black Rod, yet they keep them≈øelves ≈øo private, that be≈øides tho≈øe formerly mentioned, none hath yet been taken‚ñ™ but Colonel Croxton.

We have formerly acquainted you, That His Maje≈øty would, not touch any after the times formerly mentioned for the Evil, till further notice was given; And now le≈øt any one ≈øhould put him≈øelf to an unnece≈ø≈øary expence in attending that Cure, we are again‚ñ™ commanded to tell you, That His Maje≈øty will touch no more till about Michaelmas, of which we ≈øhall give you timely Adverti≈øement.

div.head:
Rotterdam,
Augu≈øt 9. S. N.
div.p: By Letters from Hamburg it is certified, That the Danes Forces in Hol≈øteyn are not yet disbanded, nor is there any likelyhood thereof, the report going that they daylie entertain more ≈øouldiers.

By Letters from Dantzick is confirmed the total Rout of the Mu≈øcovian Army near Grodno by General Czarnecki, where were ≈øix or ≈øeven thou≈øand ≈ølain on the Mu≈øcovian ≈øide, and a great number of Pri≈øoners taken, with all their Ammunition, Bag and Baggage; and that the Tartars and Co≈ø≈øacks have joyntly invaded Mu≈øcovia; and al≈øo that the Poles have taken Bichow (a very con≈øiderable place) by ≈øtratagem.
From Copenhagen we are informed, that the I≈øland of Zealand is not yet wholly cleared of the Swedes, although our Vice-Admiral de Ruyter u≈øeth his utmo≈øt endeavours for their Tran≈øportation.

From France we are adverti≈øed, that their Maje≈øties the King and young Queen of France, are not as yet come to Paris, but remain at Fontainbleau, until all things are fitted for their Reception, which will be mo≈øt ≈øplendid and magnificent. They make mention likewi≈øe of a great Earthquake that hapned in ≈øome parts of that Kingdom, which hath made a great ≈øpoyl, ≈ølaughter, and deva≈øtation in ≈øeveral places, throwing down of Hou≈øes, whereby many were cru≈øh'd to death, opening Mountains, and was in ≈øome places ≈øo extraordinary violent, that many of the Inhabitants were enforced to wander from their wonted habitations.
We have a report that four of our ≈øhips meeting with five Turki≈øh Pyrates, engaged with them, and after a long di≈øpute, ≈øunk two of them, and took the other three, with about 900 pri≈øoners.

div.head: Adverti≈øements.
div.p: ‚òûA White Spaniel Bitch call'd Duce) with a red Ear and a red ≈øpot on her right Side, belonging to his Grace the Duke of A ‚Ä¢ bemarle, was lo≈øt la≈øt February. He that ≈øhall bring her to any Off ‚Ä¢ cer of the Army, ≈øhall receive five pounds for his pains. If any Officer ≈øhall receive information of her, he is de≈øired to give notice of it to his Grace at the Cockpit.

A Bay Maire thirteen hand and a half high with four white feet, a blaze over the face, and a long tail, ≈øhe was lo≈øt from Hide Park on Thur≈øday the fir≈øt of this in≈øtant Augu≈øt, who ever can bring ‚Ä¢ idings of her, to the Chequer-Inn near Charing-cro≈øs, ≈øhall have good content for their pains.

TWo white Coach Goldings, ≈øtollen from Richard Peacock E≈øq on Monday night the ≈øixth of Augu≈øt, from
‚Ä¢ inchley in the County of Middle≈øex, one of them hath a lop ear on the near ≈øide, ‚Ä¢ ayl ‚Ä¢ s down t ‚Ä¢ their knees, one ≈øeven years old, the other eight, the younge≈øt hor≈øe a little galed on the ≈øide of his back. If any one can give notice to Mr. Grigge a Gold≈ømith at the Black boy over again≈øt St. Dun≈øtans-church in Fleet-≈øtreet, ≈øhall be wel rewarded for their pains.

div.head: An Adverti≈øement to all Sheriffs, Ju≈øt ‚Ä¢ ces of the Peace, Attornies, Sollicitors Clerks, Serjean ‚Ä¢ s, Bailiffs, &c.
div.p: ALl ≈øo ‚Ä¢ ts of Blank bonds, with Conditions for payment of money at a place certain, and withou ‚Ä¢ ; Counterbonds for money, and Bonds for performance of Covenants, for Arbitraments with Umpire and without Umpire; for ‚Ä¢ ppearances in any Court of Record, Counterbonds upon the ≈øame, Replevins, and Bonds upon Replevins, Bailiff ‚Ä¢ Bonds to the Sheriffs for their true performance of their Offices Bills of Sale, Bonds of Redemption, General Rel ‚Ä¢ a ‚Ä¢ es, Licences for Ale hou≈øes. All ≈øorts of warrants upon mean Proces, County-Court Warrants, &c. Warrants for Ju≈øtices of the Peace, Indentures of Apprentice≈øhip. And al≈øo the be≈øt and faire≈øt pieces Text, and flouri≈øhing for Letters Patents, Fines, Recoveries, and other Exemplifications. Are to be ≈øold by John Bellinger in Cliffords-Inn lane, Fleet≈øtreet, London.

And by him is al≈øo to be ≈øold, That mo≈øt incomparable piece of Court-hand, which (of it ≈øelf alone, without other Ma≈øter) is compleatly fitted to teach all Clerks, and others, perfectly, and exactly to write the ≈øame hand, and to read antient Records, and abreviate words.

div.head: From Lisbonne, July 18.
div.p:
As ≈øoone as news came to this place from the Amba≈ø≈øador in England De Franci≈øco De Mello, that his Maje≈øty King Charles the ≈øecond was ≈øafe in his Pallace at Whitehall, in quiet and peaceable po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of his Hereditary Kingdoms, and welcomed with ≈øo great exce≈øs of Joy that from all parts the Nobility, Gentry and Commons, came flocking to Congratulate his Arival and ki≈øs his hand. His Maje≈øty the King
of Portugal pre≈øently gave order that the ≈øame night all the great Guns of the Ca≈øtle of this Towne, and of all the Forts and Ca≈øtles of this Harbour, ≈øhould be fired in ≈øigne of his joy and contentment, which was accordingly performed, and at the ≈øame time all the Navy-≈øhips and Merchantmen in the Port, ≈øhot all their Canon. All that night the whole Citty was adorned with Luminaries. In every window of the Kings Pallace two great torches of white wax, the Amba≈ø≈øadors hou≈øe was ≈øet out in the ≈øame fa≈øhion, be≈øides in the ≈øtreets there were made very many Bonfires, rare artificial Fireworks and other inventions expre≈ø≈øing the alacrity of the Court and people very much expre≈ø≈øed by the Continual noy≈øe of Trumpets, Weights, and all ≈øorts of mu≈øicall In≈øtruments. The next morning their Maje≈øties with the Infanta went forth in ≈øolemn manner attended by all the Nobillity and Gentry of the Court and Citty, in a rich and ≈øplendid equipage to the Church of St Antony of the Capuchins, and returned to the Pallace in the ≈øame Pomp, all the bells of the towne ringing the while. By which it is plainly ≈øeen with what reall joy and ≈øatisfaction the People of this Court and Nation received this welcome news, whereof I thought good to give you notice. We have al≈øo news that ≈øome days ≈øince, on the Frontire of Alentejo, our General of Hor≈øe Alfon≈øo Turtudo, meeting with a Brigade of the Enemies Hor≈øe nigh Badajox, fought and defeated them, killed and tooke 400 of them, among≈øt the Pri≈øoners there are 4 Captains of Hor≈øe.

The next day Antonia de Souca who lived many years in London re≈øident, and acted ≈øo fervently for the King of England, as the Parliament ≈øent him home, ≈øent for many of the Cheif Engli≈øh Merchants, and gave them a treatment which co≈øt him 500 Crowns, with the greate≈øt expre≈ø≈øions of joy immaginable.

We have hitherto ≈øhewed you how ≈øeveral Regiments in the Army have been di≈øpo≈øed, we ≈øhall now give you ≈øome ≈ømall account of the ≈øettling of the Militia, and at this time onely of the County of Somer≈øet, where the Right honorable
the Marqui≈øs of Hertford is his Maje≈øties Lievtenant‚ñ™ as likewi≈øe for the County of Wilts: his Lord≈øhip hath appointed for his Deputy-Lievtenants for the County of Somer≈øet,
John Lord Paulet
Sir John Stawell
Sir Henry Berkley
Sir George Horner
Sir Tho: Bridges
Col. Edmund Windham
Edward Philips of Montagne E≈øq
Hugh Smith of Long A≈øhton E≈øq
William Waldron of Wells E≈øq

The Colonels of the Militia for that County, are
Sir Maurice Berkley Colonel of Hor≈øe, Sir Hugh Windham is Major of the ≈øame Regiment.
John Pawlet ≈øon of the Lord Pawlet.
George Stawell Son of Sir John Stawell.
Colonel Coventry.
Colonel Tho. Piggot.
Colonel Sir Francis Windham.
We ≈øhall not need to give any character of the≈øe Per≈øons, who≈øe merits are as well known throughout the whole Kingdom, as their own County.

div.head: Whitehal.
div.p: Augu≈øt 8. 1660. This day Tho: Tompkins and Herbert Perrot E≈øqs; elected Burge≈ø≈øes to ≈øerve in Parliament, for the Borough of Weebly in the County of Hereford, having taken the Oathes of Allegiance and Supremacy, were admitted into the Hou≈øe of Commons.

This day his Maje≈øty was graciou≈øly plea≈øed to confer the Honor of Knighthood on John Stapeley a Member of Parliament for Lewis in Su≈ø≈øex, a Per≈øon that hath given ≈øufficient evidences of his Loyalty, by his early appearing in the ≈øeveral Engagements that tended to the ≈øetling of his Maje≈øty in his Kingdoms.

The ≈øame day the Mayors and Bayliffs of his Maje≈øties Cinque-Ports, two antient Towns, humbly applied them≈øelves to his Highne≈øs the Duke of York, Lord Chancellor and Warden of the Cinque-ports in this their humble Petition.

body.head: To the mo≈øt Illu≈øtrious James Duke of York, Lord High-Admiral of England, Lord Warden, Chancellor and Admiral of the Cinque ports, two antient Towns and their members: The humble Petition of the Mayors, &c.
body.p: THat next unto that never to be forgotten mercy of re≈øtoring your Petitioners the Breath of their no≈øtrils and Joy of their lives, His Sacred Maje≈øty their gracious Soveraign, your Petitioners are filled with joy in the ≈øen≈øe of their extraordinary favor which His M ‚Ä¢ je≈øty hath been graciou≈øly plea≈øed to confer on your Petitioners in granting your Highne≈øs the office of Lord Warden of the Cinque-Ports, &c.

Whereby ≈øo great a door of hope is opened to your Petitioners, that in their own thoughts they ≈øeem to be in actual po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of their antient, but of late infringed Liberties and Priviledges, and dare not let a di≈øt ‚Ä¢ u≈øtful thought ≈øurpri≈øe their ≈øpirits, but hope that by the interpo≈øition of your Highne≈øs with his Maje≈øty (which they humbly pray of your Highne≈øs) his Maje≈øty will be plea≈øed to confirm and renew unto your Petitioners the Charters of the Cinque-p ‚Ä¢ rts two antient Towns and their members, granted, confi ‚Ä¢ med and renewed by his Maje≈øties noble Progenitors; and al≈øo that his Maje≈øty will be graciou≈øly plea≈øed to give ≈øpeedy and effectual relief to your Petitioners in the ≈øeveral grievances in the Schedule thereunto annexed.

div.p: His Highne≈øs having received their Petition, was plea≈øed to introduce them to his Maj ‚Ä¢ ≈øty, where being come, they pre≈øented his Maje≈øty their humble Congratulation and Addre≈øs, viz.

body.head: To the Kings mo≈øt Excellent Majesty.

The humble Congratulation and Addre≈øs of your Maje≈øties mo≈øt Loyal Subjects, the Mayors, Bayliffs, Jurates and Commons of your Maje≈øties Cinque-Ports two antient Towns, and their members, in Brotherhood and Gue≈øtling a≈ø≈øembled, 24 Iuly 1660. in the 12. year of your Maje≈øties mo≈øt happy reigne.
body.p:
THat with all po≈øsible gratitude, we do adore the wi≈øe and gracious Providence of Almighty God, in the peaceable re≈øtauration of your Sacred Maje≈øty, to the exerci≈øe of your Kingly Government, within all your Maje≈øties Dominions and Territories, and as we do upon the bended knees of our hearts, offer up our ≈øincere thanks to God for the ≈øame, ≈øo we earne≈øtly implore your Sacred Maje≈øty to receive this our Addre≈øs (though but an Evening Obligation in re≈øpect of others (the accu≈øtomed time of our Convention not ≈øooner happening) as the effect of that Duty, Loyalty and Subjection, which we acknowledge by the Laws of God, Man and Nature, to owe and yield to your Maje≈øtie, and we do take the humble boldne≈øs; to a≈ø≈øure your Maje≈øty, that in the mid≈øt of the greate≈øt defection from your Maje≈øties Government, our hearts were never tainted with ≈øo great di≈øloyalty, as by any Addre≈øs or Application what≈øoever, to te≈øtifie our A≈ø≈øent to any Government impo≈øed upon us, but faithfully retained (though forced to lie hidden in their own a≈øhes) tho≈øe lively ≈øparks of Loyalty, Love and Affection towards your Maje≈øty, as our only Supreame Soveraign, which by your Maje≈øties happy return and pre≈øence do enliven all our hearts, and break forth into
flames, never to be extingui≈øhed, but to be daily revived and renewed in our Supplications at the Throne of Grace, for your Maje≈øties pre≈øervation, and long and happy reign over us, which is, and ≈øhall be the ince≈ø≈øant prayer of &c.

closer.signed: Your Majesties most Loyal Subjects, the Mayors, Bayliffs, Jurats and Commons of the Cinque-Ports, &c.

div.p: His Maje≈øty was plea≈øed to receive this Addre≈øs with many gracious expre≈ø≈øions of his Royal favor and Princely intentions to confirm unto them the antient Priviledges they enjoyed under his Maje≈øties Predece≈ø≈øors, with what el≈øe might be de≈øired conducible to common good.

We ≈øhall now proceed according to our u≈øual cu≈øtom, to give you a further account of the di≈øpo≈øing of the Army, looking upon it as a matter of great import, and that which (as our own experience hath taught us) is either the ≈øupport or ruine of a Kingdom.
We ≈øhall therefore go on with that Regiment of which we told you Thomas Earl of O≈ø≈øory was Col. and Tho. Sheffeild Lieut. Col. in who≈øe company Martin Clifford is Lieut. and Weems En≈øign.

list.item: Edmond Sheffield Captain of the company late Captain Hookers.
Dawning Capt. of the company that was Captain Burrels.

div.p: Next we ≈øhall acquaint you with the Lord Widderingtons Regiment.

list.item: William Lord Widderington Coll. and Governor of Berwick.
Iohn Mayer Lieut, Col. and Deputy Governor of Berwick.
Ieremiah ‚Ä¢ olhur≈øt Capt. and Governor of Newca≈øtle‚ñ™
Edward Villers E≈øquire, Captain and Governor of Tinmouth.

div.p: There are be≈øides the≈øe, other Regiments in the Army di≈øpo≈øed of to ≈øuch Per≈øons, who have by their act ‚Ä¢ ngs and ≈øufferings for his late Maje≈øty of ble≈ø≈øed memory, made ≈øuch proof of their loyalty and courage, that no doubt can be made but that by their ≈øettlement the Army will be ≈øo modelled as may be mo≈øt for the ≈øervice of his Maje≈øty, and the peace and quiet of the Kingdom. Such are the Right honorable the Earl of Cleveland, and others, of who≈øe Regiments we ≈øhall give you an account in the next.
A Commi≈ø≈øion under the great ≈øeal of England was i≈ø≈øued forth, impowering Dr. Barrow and his Deputy to admini≈øt ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ the Oaths of Supremacy and Allegiance to the Soldiery in Scotland.

By Letters from Scotland we are informed, that that Kingdom is generally well ≈øatisfied, and expre≈øs their great joy for the happy re≈øtauration of his Maje≈øty to his people, by who≈øe gracious conce≈ø≈øions they are in great hopes to enjoy their antient Rights and Priviledges in as great mea≈øure as ever they had formerly.

The Letters from Ireland ≈øay, that the people there remain in a very quiet and peaceable po≈øture; That tho≈øe Per≈øons to whom the management of affairs there is entru≈øted, do carry on bu≈øine≈øs with ≈øuch prudence and moderation, as gives a check to all ≈øpirits; yet that they are in daily expectancy of a Lord Lieutenant or Lord Deputy.

There is no que≈øtion but by this time they have heard how His Maje≈øty hath been plea≈øed to appoint the Lord Roberts to execute that great Tru≈øt, which doubtle≈øs will give as great ≈øatisfaction to the people there, as their Commi≈ø≈øioners here, who look upon that Election as the greate≈øt happine≈øs that could befall that Kingdom.
London, Printed by John Macock and Tho. Newcomb, 1660.
